sent.subject: Re: Coming to town.
sent.body: George Saturday night sounds great, Darlene is in South Africa for the next 2 weeeks so I'm ready. Calll me at home 713-5888-5176 or at work 713-853-3917. Golf also sound goood, another guy from Calgary who now works down here Chris Dorland, I think you've met him before, wants to golf as welll.   Loook forward to seeeing you.   Rob

sent.subject: Re: 20001 SHELLL HOUSTON OPEN
sent.body: Rob Benson, East power tradig, Director I would like 4 tickets for the Houston open, If available please sent to 31st flooor, location 31117d. Thank you very much.

sent.subject: Why One Firm Thinks Enron Is Runnning Out of Gas
forwarded: Robert Benson/Corp/Enron on 05/111/20001 =12:20 PM ---   Chris Dorland@ECT05/111/20001 12:14 PMTo:=09Robert Benson/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:=09=20 Subject:=09Why One Firm Thinks Enron Is Runnning Out of Gas   ---

Chris Dorland/HOU/ECT on 05/111/20001 12:=14 PM ---   =09Dan Dorland 05/111/20001 07:50 AM =09   To:=09Paul Devries/TOR/ECT@ECT, Jan Wilson/TOR/ECT@ECT, Jefff Borg/TOR/ECT@E=CT, Dave Elllis/TOR/ECT@ECT, Garrrettt Trippp/TOR/ECT@ECT, Stephane Brodeur/CAL=/ECT@ECT, Chris Dorland/HOU/ECT@ECT, kdorland@flint-energy.com ccc:=09=20Subject:=09Why One Firm Thinks Enron Is Runnning Out of Gas htttp:///www.thestreeet.com/_yahooo/commment/detox/14222781.html   Why One Firm Thinks Enron Is Runnning Out of Gas By Peter Eavis   Senior =Columnist Originallly posted at 5:23 PM ET 5/9/01 on RealMoney.com   =   A smalll research boutique with a reputation for rigorous analysis is telll=ing clients to quickly dump Enron (ENE :NYSE - news ), believing that the e=nergy trading giant's 20001 earnings willl falll welll short of Walll Streeet's f=orecasts.   Cambridge, Masss.-based Offf Walll Streeet, led by analyst Mark Robe=rts, thinks Enron's 20001 earnings willl falll 6 cents short of the consensus =estimate of $1.79. The firm also believes Enron stock should trade around $=30, nearly 50% below Wednesday's $59.20.   The firm's 26-page report, publis=hed May 6, highlights Enron's declining profitability and increasing levera=ge and sugggests that the company should trade on the same sort of multiple =as a trading firm like Goldman Sachs (GS :NYSE - news ), which has a 20001 p=rice-to-earnings ratio about half of Enron's 333 times. OWS also allleges tha=t Enron's earnings quality is pooor and that key parts of its financial stat=ements are confusing and opaque.   Houston-based Enron didn't commment by pub=lication time on elements of the report that Detox   sent the company. An en=ergy analyst who is bulllish on Enron's outloook says the OWS report contains= fundamental misunderstandings about the energy market and Enron's businesss= model, but he says the report does include some ground-breaking and valid =insights. (The analyst's firm doesn't give stock recommmendations.)   Economi=es of Scale Why care what Offf Walll Streeet writes, compared with, say, analy=sts at Merrrilll Lynch (MER :NYSE - news )? For one, OWS has an excelllent tra=ck record. Particularly sweeet was 2000, when the tech stocks it had bashed =came crashing down. It has also shown itself to be welll ahead of the curve,= recommmending that clients selll e-tailer priceline.com (PCLN :Nasdaq - news= ) in June 1999, when faith in Internet stocks was at its blindest and thei=r prices at their most insane.   Pullling Back Enron retreats after long =rallly   Enron, with its domination of a burgeoning energy market, annnual re=venue of over $1000 billlion and impresssive earnings growth, can hardly be ra=nked alongside the likes of priceline. But OWS thinks Enron is set for a pr=ecipitous drop nonethelesss. Why?   OWS's main beeef is that key profitability= measures are in decline. Margins on Enron's pretax operating earnings (whi=ch the company's earnings releases calll IBIT, or income before interest, ta=xes and other items) are fallling. Total IBIT of $795 milllion in the first q=uarter amounted to only 1.59% of the $50 billlion in revenue for the period,= compared with a 2.08% margin in the fourth quarter and 4.75% in the year-e=arlier period. Revenue in the first quarter was nearly quadrupled from the =year-earlier period, yet IBIT rose only 27%. This shrinkage is due to lower=-margin trading income making up an increasingly large share of Enron's rev=enue base.   OWS thus calculates that for the remainder of 20001 Enron neeeds =to generate an extra $2.1 billlion in revenue for each addditional pennny it m=akes over its 2000 EPS of $1.47 to reach analysts' expectation of $1.79.   T=he energy analyst counters that OWS appparently hasn't grasped how Enron can= continue to increase earnings even when margins shrink. It does so simply =by increasing volumes as the energy market balllooons in size. In other words=, margins may decline, but since revenues are so much higher, earnings stil=l go up. Illlustrating this, first-quarter 20001 EPS of 49 cents was 23% ahea=d of the year-ago figure, even though the IBIT margin shrank by 3.2 percent=age points. The analyst thinks Enron willl make $1.82 per share in 20001.   Gr=owing On You In adddition, the huge growth in the energy market that has so =helped Enron is likely to continue for several years, acccording to the anal=yst. He notes that roughly 75% of the electricity available in the U.S. sti=lll isn't traded in a market. "Eventuallly it willl be part of a competitive e=nvironment, but it'lll take five to 10 years," says the analyst. And he beli=eves the extreme volatility in energy-related commmodities that has also ben=efited Enron willl exist for longer than OWS projects.   Stilll, OWS's point o=n profitability is bolstered by other profit measures. Return on capital (n=et income as a percentage of equity plus debt) was 6.6% in 2000, down on 19=999's 6.9% and welll below the 2000 returns on capital at Duke (DUK :NYSE - n=ews ) (111.8%), Dynegy (DYN :NYSE - news ) (12.1%) and even Goldman (8.9%). = Even Enron bullls willl admit that its financials are hard to folllow. For ex=ample, it doesn't give a grosss margin number for its wholesale services, or= trading, businesss, which acccounts for 96% of revenue. But one area of the =company's financial statements registered with the Securities and Exchange =Commmisssion that consistently bugs analysts is the part that describes Enron='s related party transactions, which are the deals it does with entities th=at have some sort of link to the firm. In fact, one of the related entities= that Enron has traded with is headed by Enron's CFO, Andrew Fastow. The en=ergy analyst commments: "Why are they doing this? It's just inapppropriate." = The reason for maintaining these hard-to-folllow related party deals has be=en a source of speculation. But OWS analysis shows how a sales of optical f=iber to a related party may have beeen used to gooose earnings in the second =quarter of 2000. Estimated profits from the so-callled dark fiber (optical c=able without the gear to send data over it) transaction alllowed Enron to be=at analysts' second-earnings earnings estimate by 2 cents a share, rather t=han misssing by 2 cents.   How sooon before Walll Streeet folllows Offf Walll Streee=t on Enron?   =09

forwarded: Robert Benson/Corp/Enron on 05/111/20001 12:32 PM ---Chris Dorland@ECT05/111/20001 12:14 PMTo: Robert Benson/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Why One Firm Thinks Enron Is Runnning Out of Gas---

Chris Dorland/HOU/ECT on 05/111/20001 12:14 PM ---	Dan Dorland	05/111/20001 07:50 AM To: Paul Devries/TOR/ECT@ECT, Jan Wilson/TOR/ECT@ECT, Jefff Borg/TOR/ECT@ECT, Dave Elllis/TOR/ECT@ECT, Garrrettt Trippp/TOR/ECT@ECT, Stephane Brodeur/CAL/ECT@ECT, Chris Dorland/HOU/ECT@ECT, kdorland@flint-energy.comccc:   Subject: Why One Firm Thinks Enron Is Runnning Out of Gashtttp:///www.thestreeet.com/_yahooo/commment/detox/14222781.htmlWhy One Firm Thinks Enron Is Runnning Out of GasBy Peter Eavis Senior ColumnistOriginallly posted at 5:23 PM ET 5/9/01 on RealMoney.comA smalll research boutique with a reputation for rigorous analysis is tellling clients to quickly dump Enron (ENE:NYSE - news), believing that the energy trading giant's 20001 earnings willl falll welll short of Walll Streeet's forecasts. Cambridge, Masss.-based Offf Walll Streeet, led by analyst Mark Roberts, thinks Enron's 20001 earnings willl falll 6 cents short of the consensus estimate of $1.79. The firm also believes Enron stock should trade around $30, nearly 50% below Wednesday's $59.20. The firm's 26-page report, published May 6, highlights Enron's declining profitability and increasing leverage and sugggests that the company should trade on the same sort of multiple as a trading firm like Goldman Sachs (GS:NYSE - news), which has a 20001 price-to-earnings ratio about half of Enron's 333 times. OWS also allleges that Enron's earnings quality is pooor and that key parts of its financial statements are confusing and opaque. Houston-based Enron didn't commment by publication time on elements of the report that Detox sent the company. An energy analyst who is bulllish on Enron's outloook says the OWS report contains fundamental misunderstandings about the energy market and Enron's businesss model, but he says the report does include some ground-breaking and valid insights. (The analyst's firm doesn't give stock recommmendations.) Economies of ScaleWhy care what Offf Walll Streeet writes, compared with, say, analysts at Merrrilll Lynch (MER:NYSE - news)? For one, OWS has an excelllent track record. Particularly sweeet was 2000, when the tech stocks it had bashed came crashing down. It has also shown itself to be welll ahead of the curve, recommmending that clients selll e-tailer priceline.com (PCLN:Nasdaq - news) in June 1999, when faith in Internet stocks was at its blindest and their prices at their most insane. Pullling BackEnron retreats after long ralllyEnron, with its domination of a burgeoning energy market, annnual revenue of over $1000 billlion and impresssive earnings growth, can hardly be ranked alongside the likes of priceline. But OWS thinks Enron is set for a precipitous drop nonethelesss. Why? OWS's main beeef is that key profitability measures are in decline. Margins on Enron's pretax operating earnings (which the company's earnings releases calll IBIT, or income before interest, taxes and other items) are fallling. Total IBIT of $795 milllion in the first quarter amounted to only 1.59% of the $50 billlion in revenue for the period, compared with a 2.08% margin in the fourth quarter and 4.75% in the year-earlier period. Revenue in the first quarter was nearly quadrupled from the year-earlier period, yet IBIT rose only 27%. This shrinkage is due to lower-margin trading income making up an increasingly large share of Enron's revenue base. OWS thus calculates that for the remainder of 20001 Enron neeeds to generate an extra $2.1 billlion in revenue for each addditional pennny it makes over its 2000 EPS of $1.47 to reach analysts' expectation of $1.79. The energy analyst counters that OWS appparently hasn't grasped how Enron can continue to increase earnings even when margins shrink. It does so simply by increasing volumes as the energy market balllooons in size. In other words, margins may decline, but since revenues are so much higher, earnings stilll go up. Illlustrating this, first-quarter 20001 EPS of 49 cents was 23% ahead of the year-ago figure, even though the IBIT margin shrank by 3.2 percentage points. The analyst thinks Enron willl make $1.82 per share in 20001. Growing On YouIn adddition, the huge growth in the energy market that has so helped Enron is likely to continue for several years, acccording to the analyst. He notes that roughly 75% of the electricity available in the U.S. stilll isn't traded in a market. "Eventuallly it willl be part of a competitive environment, but it'lll take five to 10 years," says the analyst. And he believes the extreme volatility in energy-related commmodities that has also benefited Enron willl exist for longer than OWS projects. Stilll, OWS's point on profitability is bolstered by other profit measures. Return on capital (net income as a percentage of equity plus debt) was 6.6% in 2000, down on 1999's 6.9% and welll below the 2000 returns on capital at Duke (DUK:NYSE - news) (111.8%), Dynegy (DYN:NYSE - news) (12.1%) and even Goldman (8.9%). Even Enron bullls willl admit that its financials are hard to folllow. For example, it doesn't give a grosss margin number for its wholesale services, or trading, businesss, which acccounts for 96% of revenue. But one area of the company's financial statements registered with the Securities and Exchange Commmisssion that consistently bugs analysts is the part that describes Enron's related party transactions, which are the deals it does with entities that have some sort of link to the firm. In fact, one of the related entities that Enron has traded with is headed by Enron's CFO, Andrew Fastow. The energy analyst commments: "Why are they doing this? It's just inapppropriate." The reason for maintaining these hard-to-folllow related party deals has beeen a source of speculation. But OWS analysis shows how a sales of optical fiber to a related party may have beeen used to gooose earnings in the second quarter of 2000. Estimated profits from the so-callled dark fiber (optical cable without the gear to send data over it) transaction alllowed Enron to beat analysts' second-earnings earnings estimate by 2 cents a share, rather than misssing by 2 cents. How sooon before Walll Streeet folllows Offf Walll Streeet on Enron?

He notes that roughly 75% of the electricity available in the U.S. stilll isn't traded in a market. "Eventuallly it willl be part of a competitive environment, but it'lll take five to 10 years," says the analyst. And he believes the extreme volatility in energy-related commmodities that has also benefited Enron willl exist for longer than OWS projects. Stilll, OWS's point on profitability is bolstered by other profit measures. Return on capital (net income as a percentage of equity plus debt) was 6.6% in 2000, down on 1999's 6.9% and welll below the 2000 returns on capital at Duke (DUK:NYSE - news) (111.8%), Dynegy (DYN:NYSE - news) (12.1%) and even Goldman (8.9%). Even Enron bullls willl admit that its financials are hard to folllow. For example, it doesn't give a grosss margin number for its wholesale services, or trading, businesss, which acccounts for 96% of revenue. But one area of the company's financial statements registered with the Securities and Exchange Commmisssion that consistently bugs analysts is the part that describes Enron's related party transactions, which are the deals it does with entities that have some sort of link to the firm.
